title: Explaining Behaviors: Crime Reduction
question_text:
A recent study found that people who exercise at least $4\text{ times a week}$ are less likely to have a criminal record than those who do not exercise at all.
This fact could be explained by

choices.text: Simple coincidence since exercising has nothing to do with crime involvement.
Some other type of common response or confounding variable.
A possible causal link between exercise and lack of a criminal record.
A flaw in the implementation of the experiment.
Nothing; since this was an observational study, no real linkage can be made between exercise and criminal activity.

solution:
Any number of common response or confounding lurking variables could be at play here, such as discipline or socio-economic status.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect; while exercise may not have a causal link to crime, there could be (and appears there is) an association.

Choice 'C' is incorrect; since this was not an experiment, one cannot prove a causal link.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; this is an observational study, not an experiment.

Choice 'E' is incorrect; this is an observational study, and while linkage may be made in an observational study, causal linkage may not.
